text:
“Flying into La Guardia at night,
looking down at the city
and you say to yourself, ‘Wow.
And I’m in charge of all that.’”

“I stand here before you today
as the elected leader

of the greatest city
of a great nation,

to which my ancestors
were brought chained

and whipped in the
hold of a slave ship.”
On New Year’s Day in 1990,

David Dinkins took command
of a city exhausted
by racial tension.
Two recent crimes —

the attack of a woman known
as the Central Park jogger

and the murder
of a black teenager —
had polarized the city.

New Yorkers hoped Dinkins
would be the peacemaker.

“I see New York as a
gorgeous mosaic
of race and religious faith,

of national origin
and sexual orientation,

of individuals whose families
arrived yesterday
and generations ago.”

“I never envisioned
being mayor.

I didn’t start out
in government saying,
‘Let me see.
I will achieve this office.
And then the next one.
And then the next one.’
That was never me.

I ran three times for
Manhattan borough president
before I succeeded.

People used to say to me,
‘What do you do?’

And I’d say, ‘I run for
borough president.’”

“When The New York Times
endorsed Dinkins
for borough president,

they praised Dinkins for his
dignity, force and clarity.”

Dinkins was not the most
inspiring or experienced leader,

but he was a
gentleman politician,
dapper and charming.

Persuading him
to run for mayor

against the incumbent,
Ed Koch, and then

to face Rudy Giuliani,
took some coaxing

by Harlem’s Democratic
power brokers.

“They persuaded me,
not that I could win,

but I had the best chance
of persons whose names
were recognizable.

I was as popular
as Jesse Jackson.

I was convinced
that I should try.”

“We have 45 seconds left
for concluding statements.
Mr. Dinkins.”

“I want to bring
people together,

not only for the
sake of our city

but for the sake
of our country.”
“And when I became mayor:

Gee, this mayor stuff
is pretty good.
And then the problems come.”

“The worst mass murder
in U.S. history.”

“Police have a manhunt on for
a rapist believed responsible

for a string of attacks
in Brooklyn.”

“No one has any reliable idea
of how many homeless people

and panhandlers
are on the subway.”

Dinkins had inherited
a city in turmoil,

crippled by crime, crack,
homelessness
and corruption scandals.

New York faced a deep recession
and record budget shortfalls.

“Governor Cuomo is
planning to fire

2,000 state workers
to help close the state’s
billion dollar budget gap.”

But the Dinkins administration
launched programs

to extend library services,
revitalize Times Square,

and it cut a deal to
build a new stadium
for the U.S. Tennis Association.

“The city didn’t build
that stadium.
The U.S.T.A. did.

What we achieved with this
was absolutely amazing.

Two weeks of the U.S. Open
generates more revenue

to the economy of the city
than the Yankees,

Mets, Knicks and Rangers
combined in a half-season.”

Dinkins also pressed his
original campaign agenda,

reducing the city’s homeless
shelter population,

rehabilitating low-income
housing and ultimately

adding thousands
of cops to the ranks,

part of a new approach
to policing

that began historic drops
in crime.

“When the future of our
young people is at risk,
so is the future of our city.”

“Safe Streets, Safe City, which
was subtitled Cops and Kids,

I think that was a
major accomplishment.

Because if police officers are
out of the cars, in the street,

they will get to know
the community,
the community will know them.

Crime went down more quickly
in our administration
than it ever has.”

Inside City Hall,
Dinkins assembled

a staff that was
historically diverse

and, he says, deeply devoted
to the underserved.

That commitment,
he says, was clear

on a night like June 6, 1993,
when a cargo ship carrying

almost 300 Chinese migrants
ran aground
in Far Rockaway, Queens.

“Pitch black, 3 or 4
o’clock in the morning,

And the usual people
you would expect,

the police commissioner,
the fire commissioner,

the health commissioner,
so forth.

And the young woman
named Elizabeth Aivars

who was in the mayor’s
office of immigrant affairs,
and she was out there.

Not because I ordered
her to come
or somebody suggested it.

She was there because
she saw her job

as protecting the rights
of immigrants.

Those are the kind
of folks we had
and that makes me real proud.”

But it was another tragic
summer night in 1991

that ultimately would
be Dinkins’ undoing.

On August 19,
in Crown Heights, Brooklyn,

a neighborhood where
Blacks and Orthodox Jews

had long lived on cramped,
uneasy streets,

a car in a rabbi’s
motorcade ran a red light

and accidentally killed
Gavin Cato,

a 7-year-old black boy
playing on the sidewalk.

Hours later, a mob
of Black teenagers

seeking revenge surrounded
Yankel Rosenbaum,
a Jewish scholar,
and stabbed him to death.
The racial tension exploded.

“The rocks and bottles
rained down periodically,

even one hitting the mayor’s
car at one point,
damaging the roof,

while he pleaded
on the steps for calm.”

“I want to avoid
further tragedy

and further hurt
and further harm.”

For three days, rioting
spiraled out of control.

Stark evidence,
critics said,

of Dinkins’ detached and
chaotic management style.

“Well you see, my position
is and remains to this day
that if there’s a fire,

it’s not the job of
the mayor to tell them

what diameter hose should
be used to put the fire out.

What I should have done is
sooner said to the police brass,
as I ultimately did,

‘What you’re doing
ain’t working, damn it.
Get it together.’”

The riots seemed to
epitomize Dinkins’ failings

not only as a leader,
but also as a peacemaker.

Blacks blasted him for
not arresting the driver
who killed Gavin Cato.

“If they’d arrested the Jew
that did it like that,

then everybody
would’ve been happy.”

Jews accused City Hall
of ordering police

to back off to let rioters
vent their rage.

“I didn’t even get out
through the gate

and 10 guys on top
of me beat me up.”

The allegations of bias
stung, Dinkins said,

and completely
ignored his history.

“I learned that,
on the one hand,

all of the things that I
had done to show support

for the Jewish community, the
times that I went to Israel,

seemed to matter damn little
when Crown Heights hit.”

A report commissioned
by Governor Mario Cuomo

eventually cleared Dinkins
of accusations

that police had been
ordered to stand down.

“There is no evidence
that anyone at City Hall

restrained the
Police Department

from taking aggressive action
during the disturbance.”

But the report
called the riots

New York City’s most extensive
racial unrest in over 20 years,

fatal ammunition in
the middle of Dinkins’

bitter re-election campaign
against Rudy Giuliani.

“I was in Crown Heights
during the pogrom.
And I was there quietly.

I was there with
friends of mine.”
“You call it a pogrom?”

“Well, the riot, whichever
you want to call it.”

Giuliani had the backing of
the mostly white police force

and white neighborhoods
in Brooklyn, Queens
and Staten Island.

“We knew it was going
to be close.
But we didn’t expect to lose.

And early Election Day,
there were people in Brooklyn,

white off-duty police officers
who were intimidating

some people in line
with questions like,

‘Have you ever been arrested?
Do you have a driver’s license?’
and things like that.

“We have heard reports that
voters in Washington Heights

are being challenged and
asked by poll watchers
for Mr. Giuliani’s campaign

to produce their passports
prior to voting.”
“My people were very upset.
Now it’s election night.
And we’re conceding.”
“My brothers and my sisters.
The people have spoken.”

“Some in my group wanted me
to demand a recount
and this, that and the other.

And wiser heads among us,
we said no,

in this country we don’t have
coups and revolutions.
We have elections.”
“You see, my friends.
Elections come and go.
Candidates come and go.

Mayors come and go, but the
life of a city must endure.

Never forget that this city
is about dignity.
It’s about decency.

It’s about the hope and
determination of working people

struggling to make a better life
for their children
and their children’s children.

My friends, the gorgeous
mosaic is alive.”
